key_insight: Spatia preserves a persistent 3D point‑cloud spatial memory and iteratively generates video clips conditioned on it (with continuous visual‑SLAM updates), enabling long‑term spatial and temporal consistency in generated videos.
problem_solved: Addresses the inability of current video generation models to maintain long‑horizon spatial and temporal consistency by providing an explicit, updatable scene representation that prevents drift and inconsistency across clips.
method: Persist a 3D scene point cloud as spatial memory that represents static scene geometry.
Iteratively generate short video clips conditioned on the spatial memory with dynamic–static disentanglement.
Continuously update the spatial memory using visual SLAM to incorporate new observations and correct drift.
impact: Improves coherence and realism in long‑horizon video generation, making models more useful for applications needing persistent scene understanding (e.g., robotics, AR/VR, simulation). It reduces temporal/spatial drift and enables incremental scene editing or capture workflows.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram showing: scene point‑cloud memory ↔ visual SLAM updater ↔ clip generator loop
Side‑by‑side sequence comparison (Spatia vs baseline) highlighting long‑term consistency
Graphic illustrating dynamic–static disentanglement: static 3D memory with overlaid dynamic object trajectories
Plot of consistency metrics over time (e.g., spatial drift, temporal coherence) comparing Spatia to baselines
paper_title: Spatia: Video Generation with Updatable Spatial Memory
paper_authors: Jinjing Zhao, Fangyun Wei, Zhening Liu, Hongyang Zhang, Chang Xu
